section.heading: Legislative declaration.

content.p: The practice of psychology is hereby declared to be a learned profession, affecting public safety, health and welfare and subject to regulation to protect the public from the practice of psychology by unqualified persons and from unprofessional conduct by persons licensed to practice psychology.

section.heading: Definitions.

content.p: As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 641.021to641.027, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.

section.heading: ï¿½Boardï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Boardï¿½ means the Board of Psychological Examiners.

section.heading: ï¿½Communityï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Communityï¿½ means the entire area customarily served by psychologists among whom a patient may reasonably choose, not merely the particular area inhabited by the patients of an individual psychologist or the particular city or place where the psychologist has his or her office.

section.heading: ï¿½Gross malpracticeï¿½ defined.

content.p: Practicing psychology or psychotherapy with a patient while the psychologist is under the influence of an alcoholic beverage as defined inNRS 202.015or any controlled substance; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Gross negligence; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Willful disregard of established methods and procedures in the practice of psychology; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Willful and consistent use of methods and procedures considered by psychologists in the community to be inappropriate or unnecessary in the cases where used.

section.heading: ï¿½Malpracticeï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Malpracticeï¿½ means failure on the part of a psychologist to exercise the degree of care, diligence and skill ordinarily exercised by psychologists in good standing in the community.

section.heading: ï¿½National examinationï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½National examinationï¿½ means the Examination for Professional Practice in Psychology in the form administered by the Association of State and Provincial Psychology Boards and approved for use in this State by the Board.

section.heading: ï¿½Patientï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Patientï¿½ means a person who consults or is examined or interviewed by a psychologist for purposes of diagnosis or treatment.

section.heading: ï¿½Practice of psychologyï¿½ defined.

content.p: Psychological testing and the evaluation of personal characteristics, including, without limitation, intelligence, personality, abilities, interests, aptitudes and neuropsychological functioning; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Counseling; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Psychoanalysis; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Psychotherapy; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Hypnosis; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Biofeedback; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Diagnosis and treatment of mental or emotional disorders and alcohol and other substance use disorders, including, without limitation, disorders of habit or conduct; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Psychological aspects of physical injury, illness, accident or disability; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Evaluation, therapy, remediation and consultation relating to the academic performance of the patient.

section.heading: ï¿½Professional incompetenceï¿½ defined.

content.p: Lack of knowledge or training; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Impaired physical or mental ability; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Dependence upon an alcoholic beverage as defined inNRS 202.015or any controlled substance.

section.heading: ï¿½Psychological assistantï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Psychological assistantï¿½ means a person registered with the Board as a psychological assistant pursuant to subsection 1 ofNRS 641.226.

section.heading: ï¿½Psychological internï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Psychological internï¿½ means a person registered with the Board as a psychological intern pursuant to subsection 2 ofNRS 641.226.

section.heading: ï¿½Psychological traineeï¿½ defined.

content.p: ï¿½Psychological traineeï¿½ means a person registered with the Board as a psychological trainee pursuant to subsection 3 ofNRS 641.226.

section.heading: ï¿½Psychologistï¿½ defined.

content.p: Is a graduate of an academic program approved by the Board and is qualified to practice psychology by reason of education, practical training and experience determined by the Board to be satisfactory; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has received from the Board a license to practice psychology.

section.heading: Applicability of chapter: Generally.

content.p: A person who is licensed as a clinical alcohol and drug counselor, licensed or certified as an alcohol and drug counselor or certified as an alcohol and drug counselor intern, a clinical alcohol and drug counselor intern, a problem gambling counselor or a problem gambling counselor intern, pursuant tochapter 641Cof NRS; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who provides or supervises the provision of peer recovery support services in accordance with the provisions ofNRS 433.622to433.641, inclusive; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person who is licensed as a behavior analyst or an assistant behavior analyst or registered as a registered behavior technician pursuant tochapter 641Dof NRS, while engaged in the practice of applied behavior analysis as defined inNRS 641D.080; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any member of the clergy, ï¿½if such a person does not commit an act described inNRS 641.440or represent himself or herself as a psychologist.

section.heading: Applicability of chapter: Practice by nonresident psychologist as consultant.

content.p: A psychologist, not a resident of Nevada and not licensed in Nevada, who is certified or licensed in another state whose requirements for certification or licensure are equivalent to the requirements of this chapter is not subject to the provisions of this chapter if the psychologist does not practice psychology in the State of Nevada for over 30 days in any 1 calendar year, and if the psychologist is invited as a consultant by a psychologist licensed in Nevada.

section.heading: Creation; number and appointment of members.

content.p: The Board of Psychological Examiners, consisting of seven members appointed by the Governor, is hereby created.

section.heading: Terms of members; limitation on consecutive terms.

content.p: After the initial term, the Governor shall appoint each member of the Board to a term of 4 years. No member of the Board may serve more than two consecutive terms.

section.heading: Qualifications of members; conflict of interest.

content.p: The Governor shall appoint to the Board: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Four members who are licensed psychologists in the State of Nevada with at least 5 years of experience in the practice of psychology after being licensed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

One member who is a licensed psychologist in the State of Nevada with at least 5 years of experience in the practice of psychology after being licensed and who is a core faculty member at a doctorate-level program or internship location that is accredited by the American Psychological Association for at least 3 years before the time of appointment. If such a licensed psychologist is not available to serve, the Governor shall appoint one member who meets the requirements set forth in paragraph
. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

One member who has resided in this State for at least 5 years and who represents the interests of persons or agencies that regularly provide health care to patients who are indigent, uninsured or unable to afford health care. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
One member who is a representative of the general public. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person is not eligible for appointment unless he or she is: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A citizen of the United States; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A resident of the State of Nevada. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The member who is a representative of the general public must not be a psychologist, an applicant or a former applicant for licensure as a psychologist, a member of a health profession, the spouse or the parent or child, by blood, marriage or adoption, of a psychologist, or a member of a household that includes a psychologist. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Board members must not have any conflicts of interest or the appearance of such conflicts in the performance of their duties as members of the Board.

section.heading: Required orientation for new members of Board; policies concerning compensation and performance review of staff.

content.p: Require each new member of the Board to complete orientation within 60 days after his or her appointment to the Board. The orientation must include, without limitation, instruction concerning: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Applicable laws and regulations, including, without limitation, the provisions ofNRS 641.230to641.320, inclusive, and the importance of complying with applicable laws and regulations in a timely manner; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Requirements concerning managing the finances of the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Establish policies concerning compensation and reviewing the performance of the staff of the Board.

section.heading: Meetings; quorum.

content.p: The Board shall hold a regular meeting at least once a year. The Board shall hold a special meeting upon a call of the President or upon the request of a majority of the members. A majority of the Board constitutes a quorum.

section.heading: Officers.

content.p: At the regular annual meeting, the Board shall elect from its membership a President and a Secretary-Treasurer, who shall hold office for 1 year and until the election and qualification of their successors.

section.heading: Seal.

content.p: The Board shall procure a seal.

section.heading: Records: Duties of Secretary-Treasurer; custody and inspection; confidentiality; exceptions.

content.p: The Secretary-Treasurer shall make and keep on behalf of the Board: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A record of all its meetings and proceedings. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A record of all violations and prosecutions under the provisions of this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A record of all examinations of applicants. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A register of all licenses and registrations. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A register of all holders of licenses and registrations. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An inventory of the property of the Board and of the State in the Boardï¿½s possession. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

These records must be kept in the office of the Board and, except as otherwise provided in this section, are subject to public inspection during normal working hours upon reasonable notice. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided inNRS 239.0115, the Board may keep the personnel records of applicants confidential. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in this section andNRS 239.0115, a complaint filed with the Board, all documents and other information filed with the complaint and all documents and other information compiled as a result of an investigation conducted to determine whether to initiate disciplinary action against a person are confidential, unless the person submits a written statement to the Board requesting that such documents and information be made public records. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The charging documents filed with the Board to initiate disciplinary action pursuant tochapter 622Aof NRS and all other documents and information considered by the Board when determining whether to impose discipline are public records. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The provisions of this section do not prohibit the Board from communicating or cooperating with or providing any documents or other information to any other licensing board or any other agency that is investigating a person, including, without limitation, a law enforcement agency.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.

content.p: The Board shall adopt regulations: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prescribing uniform standards concerning the locations at which persons obtaining supervised experience that is required for licensure by the Board provide services; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Authorizing the remote supervision, including, without limitation, electronic supervision, of persons obtaining supervised experience that is required for licensure by the Board who are working at remote sites and prescribing standards concerning such remote supervision; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Prescribing a manner by which the qualifications for the issuance or renewal of a license under the provisions of this chapter will be made available to the public such that those qualifications are clearly defined and easily understood. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The Board may make and promulgate any other rules and regulations not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter governing its procedure, the examination and licensure of applicants, the granting, refusal, revocation or suspension of licenses, the registration of persons as psychological assistants, psychological interns or psychological trainees and the practice of psychology. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

On the date that the Board gives notice pursuant toNRS 233B.060of its intent to adopt, amend or repeal a regulation, the Board shall submit the regulation to the Commission on Behavioral Health for review. The Commission shall review the regulation and make recommendations to the Board concerning the advisability of adopting, amending or repealing the regulation and any changes that the Commission deems advisable.

section.heading: General powers; prohibition on participation in preparing, conducting or grading examination.

content.p: The Board may, under the provisions of this chapter: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Examine and pass upon the qualifications of the applicants for licensure. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
License qualified applicants. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Register a person as a psychological assistant, psychological intern or psychological trainee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Revoke or suspend licenses and registrations. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Collect all fees and make disbursements pursuant to this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The member of the Board who is a representative of the general public shall not participate in preparing, conducting or grading any examination required by the Board.

section.heading: Board may enter into agreement with Department of Health and Human Services for certain types of administrative assistance.

content.p: Technical assistance; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Recommendations to improve and standardize procedures used by the Board; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Assistance in identifying resources for improving the operations of the Board.

section.heading: Deposit and expenditure of money.

content.p: All money coming into possession of the Board must be kept or deposited by the Secretary-Treasurer in banks, credit unions, savings and loan associations or savings banks in the State of Nevada to be expended for payment of compensation and expenses of board members and for other necessary or proper purposes in the administration of this chapter.

section.heading: Duty of psychologist to limit practice to areas of competence; enforcement; regulations.

content.p: A licensed psychologist shall limit his or her practice of psychology to his or her areas of competence, as documented by education, training and experience. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Board shall ensure, by adopting regulations and enforcing the provisions of this chapter, that licensed psychologists limit their practice of psychology to their areas of competence.

section.heading: Registration of firm, partnership or corporation which engages in or offers to engage in practice of psychology; regulations; penalty.

content.p: [Replaced in revision byNRS 641.2265.]

section.heading: Offices; employees; prohibition on payment of expenses out of State General Fund.

content.p: The Board may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Maintain offices in as many localities in the State as it considers necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Employ attorneys, investigators, consultants, hearings officers and employees necessary to the discharge of its duties. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any expense incurred by the Board may not be paid out of the State General Fund.

section.heading: Forms for licensure.

content.p: Provide immediate, automatic feedback to the applicant concerning whether the applicant has submitted all required information; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Automatically store the data submitted by the applicant upon completion of the application.

section.heading: Hearings and investigations; taking evidence.

content.p: In a manner consistent with the provisions ofchapter 622Aof NRS, the Board may hold hearings and conduct investigations related to its duties under this chapter and take evidence on any matter under inquiry before it.

section.heading: Civil liability.

content.p: A member of the Board or an employee or agent of the Board is not liable in a civil action for any act performed in good faith and within the scope of the duties of the Board pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.

section.heading: Salary of members; per diem allowance and travel expenses of members and employees; payment of compensation and expenses of members and employees.

content.p: Each member of the Board is entitled to receive: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A salary of not more than $150 per day, as fixed by the Board, while engaged in the business of the Board; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A per diem allowance and travel expenses at a rate fixed by the Board, while engaged in the business of the Board. The rate must not exceed the rate provided for state officers and employees generally. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

While engaged in the business of the Board, each employee of the Board is entitled to receive a per diem allowance and travel expenses at a rate fixed by the Board. The rate must not exceed the rate provided for state officers and employees generally. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Compensation and expenses of the members and employees of the Board are payable out of the money derived from fees paid or transmitted to the Board pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, and no part thereof may be paid out of the State Treasury.

section.heading: Annual report to Joint Interim Standing Committee on Health and Human Services and Chairs of regional behavioral health policy boards.

content.p: On or before February 1 of each year, the Board shall submit to the Joint Interim Standing Committee on Health and Human Services and to the Chair of each regional behavioral health policy board created byNRS 433.429a report which must include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The number of complaints received, investigations completed, cases dismissed, cases settled and cases for which hearings were held within the immediately preceding calendar year; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The number of applications for the issuance or renewal of a license or registration received by the Board during the immediately preceding calendar year and the number of those applications for which the Board conducted additional review beyond the standard review regularly conducted by the Board; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The number of applications for the issuance of a license by endorsement received by the Board pursuant toNRS 641.196during the immediately preceding calendar year, the number of those applications that were denied and the reasons for denial. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The report submitted pursuant to this section to the Chair of each regional behavioral health policy board created byNRS 433.429may be submitted in a written format.

section.heading: Application and fee for license.

content.p: Each person desiring a license must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Make application to the Board upon a form, and in a manner, prescribed by the Board pursuant toNRS 641.117. The application must be accompanied by the application fee prescribed by the Board and include all information required to complete the application. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As part of the application and at his or her own expense: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Arrange to have a complete set of fingerprints taken by a law enforcement agency or other authorized entity acceptable to the Board; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Submit to the Board: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) A complete set of fingerprints and written permission authorizing the Board to forward the fingerprints to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a report on the applicantï¿½s background, and to such other law enforcement agencies as the Board deems necessary for a report on the applicantï¿½s background; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) Written verification, on a form prescribed by the Board, stating that the set of fingerprints of the applicant was taken and directly forwarded electronically or by other means to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History and that the applicant provided written permission authorizing the law enforcement agency or other authorized entity taking the fingerprints to submit the fingerprints to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a report on the applicantï¿½s background, and to such other law enforcement agencies as the Board deems necessary for a report on the applicantï¿½s background. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Board may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unless the applicantï¿½s fingerprints are directly forwarded pursuant to sub-subparagraph (II) of subparagraph
of paragraph

of subsection 1, submit those fingerprints to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and to such other law enforcement agencies as the Board deems necessary; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Request from each agency to which the Board submits the fingerprints any information regarding the applicantï¿½s background as the Board deems necessary. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An application is not considered complete and received for purposes of evaluation pursuant to subsection 2 ofNRS 641.170until the Board receives a complete set of fingerprints or verification that the fingerprints have been forwarded electronically or by other means to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History, and written authorization from the applicant pursuant to this section.

section.heading: Qualifications of applicants for licensure; Board required to evaluate application and issue statement of determination; contents of statement.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided inNRS 641.196, each application for licensure as a psychologist must be accompanied by evidence satisfactory to the Board that the applicant: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is at least 21 years of age. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is of good moral character as determined by the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Has earned a doctorate in psychology from an accredited educational institution approved by the Board, or has other doctorate-level training from an accredited educational institution deemed equivalent by the Board in both subject matter and extent of training. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Has at least 2 years of experience satisfactory to the Board, 1 year of which must be postdoctoral experience in accordance with the requirements established by regulations of the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided inNRS 641.196, within 120 days after receiving an application and the accompanying evidence from an applicant, the Board shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Evaluate the application and accompanying evidence and determine whether the applicant is qualified pursuant to this section for licensure; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Issue a written statement to the applicant of its determination. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The written statement issued to the applicant pursuant to subsection 2 must include: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the Board determines that the qualifications of the applicant are insufficient for licensure, a detailed explanation of the reasons for that determination. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the applicant for licensure as a psychologist has not earned a doctorate in psychology from an accredited educational institution approved by the Board and the Board determines that the doctorate-level training from an accredited educational institution is not equivalent in subject matter and extent of training, a detailed explanation of the reasons for that determination.

section.heading: Application for license or registration: Submission of official transcripts by alternate means.

content.p: The college or university from which the applicant graduated has closed or has merged with another institution; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The provision of official transcripts by ordinary means is not available or possible.

section.heading: Payment of child support: Submission of certain information by applicant; grounds for denial of license or registration; duty of Board. [Effective until the date of the repeal of 42 U.S.C. ï¿½ 666, the federal law requiring each state to establish procedures for withholding, suspending and restricting the professional, occupational and recreational licenses for child support arrearages and for noncompliance with certain processes relating to paternity or child support proceedings.]

content.p: In addition to any other requirements set forth in this chapter: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An applicant for the issuance of a license or registration shall include the social security number of the applicant in the application submitted to the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An applicant for the issuance or renewal of a license or registration shall submit to the Board the statement prescribed by the Division of Welfare and Supportive Services of the Department of Health and Human Services pursuant toNRS 425.520. The statement must be completed and signed by the applicant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Board shall include the statement required pursuant to subsection 1 in: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The application or any other forms that must be submitted for the issuance or renewal of the license or registration; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A separate form prescribed by the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A license or registration may not be issued or renewed by the Board if the applicant: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Fails to submit the statement required pursuant to subsection 1; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Indicates on the statement submitted pursuant to subsection 1 that the applicant is subject to a court order for the support of a child and is not in compliance with the order or a plan approved by the district attorney or other public agency enforcing the order for the repayment of the amount owed pursuant to the order. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If an applicant indicates on the statement submitted pursuant to subsection 1 that the applicant is subject to a court order for the support of a child and is not in compliance with the order or a plan approved by the district attorney or other public agency enforcing the order for the repayment of the amount owed pursuant to the order, the Board shall advise the applicant to contact the district attorney or other public agency enforcing the order to determine the actions that the applicant may take to satisfy the arrearage.

section.heading: Examination of applicant for license as psychologist; waiver.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided inNRS 641.180,641.190and641.196, each applicant for a license as a psychologist must pass the national examination. In addition to the national examination, the Board may require an examination in whatever applied or theoretical fields it deems appropriate. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Board shall notify each applicant of the results of the national examination and any other examination required pursuant to subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Board may waive the requirement of the national examination for a person who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is licensed in another state; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has at least 10 yearsï¿½ experience; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is a diplomate in the American Board of Professional Psychology or a fellow in the American Psychological Association, or who has other equivalent status as determined by the Board.

section.heading: Licensing or limited practice authorization of psychologist licensed or certified in another state.

content.p: Grant a license as a psychologist without any examination to any person certified or licensed by a board of psychological examiners of another state if the Board determines that the requirements in that state are at least equivalent to the requirements of this chapter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Authorize a psychologist licensed or certified pursuant to the laws of another state to practice psychology for 1 year or less if the psychologist has: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Made application to the Board for licensure; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Met the requirements of education and experience for licensure in this State; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Not been disciplined in another state in connection with a license to practice psychology or has not committed any act in another state which is a violation of this chapter.

section.heading: Expedited license by endorsement as psychologist: Requirements; procedure for issuance; provisional license pending action on application.

content.p: The Board may issue a license by endorsement as a psychologist to an applicant who meets the requirements set forth in this section. An applicant may submit to the Board an application for such a license if the applicant holds a corresponding valid and unrestricted license as a psychologist in the District of Columbia or any state or territory of the United States. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An applicant for a license by endorsement pursuant to this section must submit to the Board with his or her application: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Proof satisfactory to the Board that the applicant: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Has not been disciplined or investigated by the corresponding regulatory authority of the District of Columbia or the state or territory in which the applicant holds a license as a psychologist; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has not been held civilly or criminally liable for malpractice in the District of Columbia or any state or territory of the United States; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A complete set of fingerprints and written permission authorizing the Board to forward the fingerprints in the manner provided inNRS 641.160; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The fee prescribed by the Board pursuant toNRS 641.228for the issuance of an initial license; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other information required by the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Not later than 15 business days after receiving an application for a license by endorsement as a psychologist pursuant to this section, the Board shall provide written notice to the applicant of any additional information required by the Board to consider the application. Unless the Board denies the application for good cause, the Board shall approve the application and issue a license by endorsement as a psychologist to the applicant not later than 45 days after receiving all the additional information required by the Board to complete the application. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A license by endorsement as a psychologist may be issued at a meeting of the Board or between its meetings by the President of the Board. Such an action shall be deemed to be an action of the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

At any time before making a final decision on an application for a license by endorsement pursuant to this section, the Board may, for any reason, grant a provisional license authorizing an applicant to practice as a psychologist in accordance with regulations adopted by the Board.

section.heading: Renewal of license: Application; fee; declaration of areas of competence by psychologist; continuing education.

content.p: To renew a license issued pursuant to this chapter, each person must, on or before the first day of January of each odd-numbered year: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Apply to the Board for renewal; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Submit evidence to the Board of completion of the requirements for continuing education as set forth in regulations adopted by the Board; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Submit all information required to complete the renewal. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Upon renewing his or her license, a psychologist shall declare his or her areas of competence, as determined in accordance withNRS 641.112. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Board shall, as a prerequisite for the renewal of a license, require each holder to comply with the requirements for continuing education adopted by the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The requirements for continuing education adopted by the Board pursuant to subsection 3 must include, without limitation: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A requirement that the holder of a license receive at least 2 hours of instruction on evidence-based suicide prevention and awareness or another course of instruction on suicide prevention and awareness that is approved by the Board which the Board has determined to be effective and appropriate. The hours of instruction required by this paragraph must be completed within 2 years after initial licensure and at least every 4 years thereafter. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A requirement that the holder of a license must biennially receive at least 6 hours of instruction relating to cultural competency and diversity, equity and inclusion. Such instruction: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
May include the training provided pursuant toNRS 449.103, where applicable. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Must be based upon a range of research from diverse sources. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

section.heading: Renewal of license: Duty of Board to require applicant to report receipt of training in treatment of mental and emotional trauma and willingness to respond during emergency or disaster; maintenance and provision of related lists of names by Board; failure of applicant to comply not ground for denial; confidentiality of information.

content.p: The Board shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Require each applicant for the renewal of a license as a psychologist to: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Report whether he or she has received training in the treatment of mental and emotional trauma immediately following an emergency or disaster, training in the short-term treatment of mental and emotional trauma or training in the long-term treatment of mental and emotional trauma; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the applicant has received training in the treatment of mental and emotional trauma immediately following an emergency or disaster, describe the training and indicate if he or she is willing to respond immediately should an emergency or disaster arise at any location in this State; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Maintain a list of each licensed psychologist and any training described in subparagraph
of paragraph
that the licensee has received and update the list at least annually to include information reported pursuant to paragraph

Maintain a list of the names and contact information for psychologists who indicate that they are willing to respond immediately should an emergency or disaster arise at any location in this State and whom the Board has determined have appropriate training to respond following an emergency or disaster; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Provide the lists maintained pursuant to paragraphs
and
upon request to a governmental entity responding to a state of emergency or declaration of a disaster by the Governor or the Legislature pursuant toNRS 414.070. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Board shall not deny the renewal of a license as a psychologist solely because the applicant has failed to comply with the requirements of paragraph
of subsection 1. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided in paragraph
of subsection 1, any information obtained or maintained by the Board pursuant to this section is confidential.

section.heading: Renewal of license or registration: Duty of Board to make data request concerning demographic and practice information available to applicants for voluntary completion and electronic submission; confidentiality of information provided.

content.p: The Board shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Make the data request developed by the Director of the Department of Health and Human Services pursuant toNRS 439A.116available to applicants for the renewal of a license or registration pursuant to this chapter through a link on the electronic application for the renewal of a license or registration; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Request each applicant to complete and electronically submit the data request to the Director. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The information provided by an applicant for the renewal of a license or registration pursuant to subsection 1 is confidential and, except as required by subsection 1, must not be disclosed to any person or entity. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An applicant for the renewal of a license or registration is not required to complete a data request pursuant to subsection 1 and is not subject to disciplinary action, including, without limitation, refusal to renew the license or registration, for failure to do so.

section.heading: Automatic suspension of psychologistï¿½s license for failure to pay biennial fee for renewal of license; reinstatement; notice of suspension.

content.p: The license of any person who fails to pay the biennial fee for the renewal of a license within 60 days after the date when it is due is automatically suspended. The Board may, within 2 years after the date the license is so suspended, reinstate the license upon payment to the Board of the amount of the then current biennial fee for the renewal of a license and the amount of the fee for the restoration of a license so suspended. If the license is not reinstated within 2 years, the Board may reinstate the license only if it also determines that the holder of the license is competent to practice psychology. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A notice must be sent to any person who fails to pay the biennial fee, informing the person that the license is suspended.

section.heading: Psychologist required to practice under name that appears on license; association with firm, partnership or corporation authorized under certain circumstances.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, a psychologist may practice only under the name that appears on the license to practice psychology issued to the psychologist by the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A psychologist may associate with a firm, partnership or corporation which engages in or offers to engage in the practice of psychology if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The firm, partnership or corporation is registered with the Board; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The name and license of each psychologist associated with the firm, partnership or corporation is displayed conspicuously at the place where he or she practices psychology.

section.heading: Registration: Application; fee; fingerprints; expiration; renewal; supervision; regulations.

content.p: A person who wishes to obtain any postdoctoral supervised experience that is required for licensure as a psychologist pursuant to paragraph
of subsection 1 ofNRS 641.170must register with the Board as a psychological assistant. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Is in a doctoral training program in psychology at an accredited educational institution approved by the Board or in doctorate-level training from an accredited educational institution deemed equivalent by the Board in both subject matter and extent of training; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Wishes to engage in a predoctoral internship pursuant to the requirements of the training program, ï¿½may register with the Board as a psychological intern. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person who: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Is in a doctoral training program in psychology at an accredited educational institution approved by the Board or in doctorate-level training from an accredited educational institution deemed equivalent by the Board in both subject matter and extent of training; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Wishes to perform professional activities or services under the supervision of a psychologist, ï¿½may register with the Board as a psychological trainee. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person desiring to register as a psychological assistant, psychological intern or psychological trainee must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Make application to the Board on a form, and in a manner, prescribed by the Board. The application must be accompanied by the application fee prescribed by the Board and include all information required to complete the application. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As part of the application and at his or her own expense: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Arrange to have a complete set of fingerprints taken by a law enforcement agency or other authorized entity acceptable to the Board; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Submit to the Board: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (I) A complete set of fingerprints, a fee for the processing of fingerprints established by the Board and written permission authorizing the Board to forward the fingerprints to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a report on the applicantï¿½s background, and to such other law enforcement agencies as the Board deems necessary for a report on the applicantï¿½s background; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ (II) Written verification, on a form prescribed by the Board, stating that the set of fingerprints of the applicant was taken and directly forwarded electronically or by other means to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History and that the applicant provided written permission authorizing the law enforcement agency or other authorized entity taking the fingerprints to submit the fingerprints to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for a report on the applicantï¿½s background, and to such other law enforcement agencies as the Board deems necessary for a report on the applicantï¿½s background. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Board may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unless the applicantï¿½s fingerprints are directly forwarded pursuant to sub-subparagraph (II) of subparagraph
of paragraph

of subsection 4, submit those fingerprints to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History for submission to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and to such other law enforcement agencies as the Board deems necessary; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Request from each agency to which the Board submits the fingerprints any information regarding the applicantï¿½s background as the Board deems necessary. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An application for initial registration as a psychological assistant, psychological intern or psychological trainee is not considered complete and received until the Board receives: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A complete set of fingerprints or verification that the fingerprints have been forwarded electronically or by other means to the Central Repository for Nevada Records of Criminal History, and written authorization from the applicant pursuant to this section; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The fee for the initial registration of a psychological assistant, psychological intern or psychological trainee that is prescribed by the Board pursuant toNRS 641.228. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A registration as a: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Psychological assistant expires 1 year after the date of registration unless the registration is renewed pursuant to subsection 8. A registration as a psychological assistant may not be renewed if the renewal would cause the psychological assistant to be registered as a psychological assistant for more than 3 years unless otherwise approved by the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Psychological intern expires 2 years after the date of registration and may not be renewed unless otherwise approved by the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Psychological trainee expires 2 years after the date of registration unless the registration is renewed pursuant to subsection 8. A registration as a psychological trainee may not be renewed if the renewal would cause the psychological trainee to be registered as a psychological trainee for more than 5 years unless otherwise approved by the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To renew a registration as a psychological assistant, psychological intern or psychological trainee, the registrant must, on or before the expiration of the registration: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Apply to the Board for renewal; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Pay the fee prescribed by the Board pursuant toNRS 641.228for the renewal of a registration as a psychological assistant, psychological intern or psychological trainee; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Submit all information required to complete the renewal. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Any activity or service performed by a psychological assistant, psychological intern or psychological trainee must be performed under the supervision of a psychologist in accordance with regulations adopted by the Board.

section.heading: Requirement; regulations; penalty.

content.p: A firm, partnership or corporation which engages in or offers to engage in the practice of psychology shall register with the Board. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The Board shall adopt regulations which prescribe the requirements for such registration. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any firm, partnership or corporation which violates the provisions of subsection 1 is guilty of a gross misdemeanor.

section.heading: Text of Compact.

content.p: Increase public access to professional psychological services by allowing for telepsychological practice across state lines, as well as temporary in-person, face-to-face services, into a state which the psychologist is not licensed to practice psychology; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Facilitate the exchange of information between the compact states regarding psychologist licensure, adverse actions and disciplinary history; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Promote compliance with the laws governing psychological practice in each compact state; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Invest all compact states with the authority to hold licensed psychologists accountable through the mutual recognition of compact state licenses. ARTICLE II. Definitions ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ A. ï¿½Adverse actionï¿½ means any action taken by a state psychology regulatory authority which finds a violation of a statute or regulation that is identified by the state psychology regulatory authority as discipline and is a matter of public record. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ B. ï¿½Association of State and Provincial Psychology Boards (ASPPB)ï¿½ means the recognized membership organization composed of state and provincial psychology regulatory authorities responsible for the licensure and registration of psychologists throughout the United States and Canada. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ C. ï¿½Authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychologyï¿½ means a licensed psychologistï¿½s authority to practice telepsychology, within the limits authorized under this Compact, in another compact state. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ D. ï¿½Bylawsï¿½ means those bylaws established by the Psychology Interjurisdictional Compact Commission pursuant to Article X for its governance, or for directing and controlling its actions and conduct. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ E. ï¿½Client/patientï¿½ means the recipient of psychological services, whether psychological services are delivered in the context of healthcare, corporate, supervision and/or consulting services. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ F. ï¿½Commissionerï¿½ means the voting representative appointed by each state psychology regulatory authority pursuant to Article X. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ G. ï¿½Compact stateï¿½ means a state, the District of Columbia or United States territory that has enacted this Compact and which has not withdrawn pursuant to Article XIII, section C or been terminated pursuant to Article XII, section B. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ H. ï¿½Coordinated Licensure Information Systemï¿½ or ï¿½Coordinated Databaseï¿½ means an integrated process for collecting, storing and sharing information on psychologistsï¿½ licensure and enforcement activities related to psychology licensure laws, which is administered by the recognized membership organization composed of the state psychology regulatory authorities. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ I. ï¿½Confidentialityï¿½ means the principle that data or information is not made available or disclosed to unauthorized persons or processes. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ J. ï¿½Dayï¿½ means any part of a day in which psychological work is performed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ K. ï¿½Distant stateï¿½ means the compact state where a psychologist is physically present, not through using telecommunications technologies, to provide temporary in-person, face-to-face psychological services. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ L. ï¿½E.Passportï¿½ means a certificate issued by the Association of State and Provincial Psychology Boards (ASPPB) that promotes the standardization in the criteria of interjurisdictional telepsychology practice and facilitates the process for licensed psychologists to provide telepsychological services across state lines. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ M. ï¿½Executive Boardï¿½ means a group of directors elected or appointed to act on behalf of, and within the powers granted to them by, the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ N. ï¿½Home stateï¿½ means a compact state where a psychologist is licensed to practice psychology. If the psychologist is licensed in more than one compact state, and is practicing under the authorization to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology, the home state is the compact state where the psychologist was physically present when the telepsychological services were delivered. If the psychologist is licensed in more than one compact state and is practicing under the temporary authorization to practice, the home state is any compact state where the psychologist is licensed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ O. ï¿½Identity history summaryï¿½ means a summary of information retained by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, or other designee with similar authority, in connection with arrests and, in some instances, federal employment, naturalization or military service. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ P. ï¿½In-person, face-to-faceï¿½ means interactions in which the psychologist and the client/patient are in the same physical space and which does not include interactions that may occur through the use of telecommunication technologies. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Q. ï¿½Interjurisdictional practice certificate (IPC)ï¿½ means a certificate issued by the Association of State and Provincial Psychology Boards (ASPPB) that grants temporary authority to practice based on notification to the state psychology regulatory authority of the intention to practice temporarily, and verification of oneï¿½s qualifications for such practice. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ R. ï¿½Licenseï¿½ means authorization by a state psychology regulatory authority to engage in the independent practice of psychology, which would be unlawful without the authorization. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ S. ï¿½Noncompact stateï¿½ means any state which is not at

Investigative information that a state psychology regulatory authority, after a preliminary inquiry that includes notification and an opportunity to respond if required by state law, has reason to believe, if proven true, would indicate more than a violation of state statute or ethics code that would be considered more substantial than a minor infraction; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Investigative information that indicates that the psychologist represents an immediate threat to the public health and safety, regardless of whether the psychologist has been notified or had an opportunity to respond. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Y. ï¿½Stateï¿½ means a state, commonwealth, territory or possession of the United States or the District of Columbia. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ Z. ï¿½State psychology regulatory authorityï¿½ means the board, office or other agency with the legislative mandate to license and regulate the practice of psychology. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ AA. ï¿½Telepsychologyï¿½ means the provision of psychological services using telecommunication technologies. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ BB. ï¿½Temporary authorization to practiceï¿½ means a licensed psychologistï¿½s authority to conduct temporary in-person, face-to-face practice, within the limits authorized under this Compact, in another compact state. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ CC. ï¿½Temporary in-person, face-to-face practiceï¿½ means where a psychologist is physically present, not through using telecommunications technologies, in the distant state to provide for the practice of psychology for 30 days within a calendar year and based on notification to the distant state. ARTICLE III. Home State Licensure ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ A. The home state shall be a compact state where a psychologist is licensed to practice psychology. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ B. A psychologist may hold one or more compact state licenses at a time. If the psychologist is licensed in more than one compact state, the home state is the compact state where the psychologist was physically present when the services were delivered as authorized by the authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology under the terms of this Compact. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ C. Any compact state may require a psychologist not previously licensed in a compact state to obtain and retain a license to be authorized to practice in the compact state under circumstances not authorized by the authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology under the terms of this Compact. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ D. Any compact state may require a psychologist to obtain and retain a license to be authorized to practice in a compact state under circumstances not authorized by the temporary authorization to practice under the terms of this Compact. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ E. A home stateï¿½s license authorizes a psychologist to practice in a receiving state under the authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology only if the compact state: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Notifies the Commission, in compliance with the terms herein, of any adverse action or significant investigatory information regarding a licensed individual; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Requires an identity history summary of all applicants at initial licensure, including the use of the results of fingerprints or other biometric data checks compliant with the requirements of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, or other designee with similar authority, not later than 10 years after activation of the Compact; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Complies with the bylaws and rules of the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ F. A home stateï¿½s license grants temporary authorization to practice to a psychologist in a distant state only if the compact state: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Notifies the Commission, in compliance with the terms herein, of any adverse action or significant investigatory information regarding a licensed individual; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Requires an identity history summary of all applicants at initial licensure, including the use of the results of fingerprints or other biometric data checks compliant with the requirements of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, or other designee with similar authority, not later than 10 years after activation of the Compact; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Complies with the bylaws and rules of the Commission. ARTICLE IV. Compact Privilege to Practice Telepsychology ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ A. Compact states shall recognize the right of a psychologist, licensed in a compact state in conformance with Article III, to practice telepsychology in other compact states (receiving states) in which the psychologist is not licensed, under the authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology as provided in the Compact. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ B. To exercise the authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology under the terms and provisions of this Compact, a psychologist licensed to practice in a compact state must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Hold a graduate degree in psychology from an institute of higher education that was, at the time the degree was awarded: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a. Regionally accredited by an accrediting body recognized by the United States Department of Education to grant graduate degrees or authorized by provincial statute or royal charter to grant doctoral degrees; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ b. A foreign college or university deemed to be equivalent to 1

above by a foreign credential evaluation service that is a member of the National Association of Credential Evaluation Services (NACES) or by a recognized foreign credential evaluation service; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Hold a graduate degree in psychology that meets the following criteria: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a. The program, wherever it may be administratively housed, must be clearly identified and labeled as a psychology program and such a program must specify in pertinent institutional catalogues and brochures its intent to educate and train professional psychologists; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ b. The psychology program must stand as a recognizable, coherent organizational entity within the institution; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ c. There must be a clear authority and primary responsibility for the core and specialty areas whether or not the program cuts across administrative lines; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ d. The program must consist of an integrated, organized sequence of study; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ e. There must be an identifiable psychology faculty sufficient in size and breadth to carry out its responsibilities; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ f. The designated director of the program must be a psychologist and a member of the core faculty; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ g. The program must have an identifiable body of students who are matriculated in that program for a degree; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ h. The program must include supervised practicum, internship or field training appropriate to the practice of psychology; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ i. The curriculum shall encompass a minimum of 3 academic years of full-time graduate study for doctoral degrees and a minimum of 1 academic year of full-time graduate study for masterï¿½s degrees; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ j. The program must include an acceptable residency as defined by the rules of the Commission; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Possess a current, full and unrestricted license to practice psychology in a home state which is a compact state; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Have no criminal record history reported on an identity history summary that violates the rules of the Commission; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Provide attestations in regard to areas of intended practice, conformity with standards of practice, competence in telepsychology technology, criminal background and knowledge and adherence to legal requirements in the home and receiving states, and provide a release of information to allow for primary source verification in a manner specified by the Commission; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Meet other criteria as defined by the rules of the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ C. The home state maintains authority over the license of any psychologist practicing into a receiving state under the authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ D. A psychologist practicing into a receiving state under the authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology will be subject to the receiving stateï¿½s scope of practice. A receiving state may, in accordance with that stateï¿½s due process law, limit or revoke a psychologistï¿½s authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology in the receiving state and may take any other necessary actions under the receiving stateï¿½s applicable law to protect the health and safety of the receiving stateï¿½s citizens. If a receiving state takes action, the state shall promptly notify the home state and the Commission. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ E. If a psychologistï¿½s license in any home state or another compact state or any authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology in any receiving state is restricted, suspended or otherwise limited, the E.Passport shall be revoked and therefore the psychologist shall not be eligible to practice telepsychology in a compact state under the authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology. ARTICLE V. Compact Temporary Authorization to Practice ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ A. Compact states shall also recognize the right of a psychologist, licensed in a compact state in conformance with Article III, to practice temporarily in other compact states (distant states) in which the psychologist is not licensed, as provided in the Compact. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ B. To exercise the temporary authorization to practice under the terms and provisions of this Compact, a psychologist licensed to practice in a compact state must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A foreign college or university deemed to be equivalent to 1

above by a foreign credential evaluation service that is a member of the National Association of Credential Evaluation Services (NACES) or by a recognized foreign credential evaluation service; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Hold a graduate degree in psychology that meets the following criteria: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ a. The program, wherever it may be administratively housed, must be clearly identified and labeled as a psychology program and must specify in pertinent institutional catalogues and brochures its intent to educate and train professional psychologists; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ b. Conditions of Telepsychology Practice in a Receiving State ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ A psychologist may practice in a receiving state under the authority to practice interjurisdictional telepsychology only in the performance of the scope of practice for psychology as assigned by an appropriate state psychology regulatory authority, as defined in the rules of the Commission, and under the following circumstances: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ A. Other conditions regarding telepsychology as determined by rules promulgated by the Commission. ARTICLE VII. Adverse Actions ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ A. A home state shall have the power to impose adverse action against a psychologistï¿½s license issued by the home state and a distant state may take adverse action on a psychologistï¿½s temporary authorization to practice within that distant state. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ B.
